content: I'm somewhat surprised about the Table under HumanName listing "Mr" as an example for HumanName.prefix. http://build.fhir.org/datatypes.html#HumanName

That's inconsistent with the other exmples here: http://build.fhir.org/datatypes-examples.html#HumanName which use prefix for academic or other titles.
IMO, "Mr." or "Mrs." shouldn't be represented as a part of the name.

"Mr." is part of the string that you'd use when printing out someone's name - just like "Dr." or "Professor" or "Miss" or any of a number of other things. If it's part of the name string, it must be a name part, and it certainly fits the criteria for being a "prefix". There can be different types of prefixes and suffixes that indicate a variety of things - gender, marital status, professional status, education, etc. If you just have "prefix", there's no way to tell what the meaning is. There are extensions that can let you differentiate though. Look at http://build.fhir.org/extension-iso21090-en-qualifier.html

I'm not convinced that "Mr."/"Mrs."/"Ms."/whatever should be part of the name.
Like: if I want to use that extension, what would be the right code for a prefix="Mr." out of the corresponding value set http://build.fhir.org/valueset-name-part-qualifier.html ?

Maybe it is also an issue of regional perception, whether some kind of gender is part of the name...

Well, the question is if you want the mailing envelope to say "Mr. Lloyd McKenzie" or "Dr. Jane Smith", where else are you going to get the "Mr." or "Dr." from? There are lots of systems that store and display such prefixes and every one I've seen captures the information as part of the name.

We've had this discussion in a v2 context, as well as in v3. Which just goes to show that different contexts/countries deal with this in different ways. In quite a few European countries Mr/Ms is auto-generated based on the value of Patient.gender, and not part of the name itself. In Sweden they check whether the national person number is odd or even, which is an indication of gender and thus an indication of whether Mr or Ms should be used. Quite often for minors the use of Mr/Ms is omitted, and the full given name is used. All of this is supported by the FHIR datatype, how one uses it is up to the context.
Note that Dr. would be part of the name in most European countries I know of (the discussion above is solely about Mr/Ms)

Using "Mr." on the mail envelope is mostly deprecated over here, whereas our business letter to Dr. Jane Smith would begin with:
"Sehr geehrte Frau Dr. Smith", which 1:1-translates to "Dear Mrs. Dr. Smith" ...
And it's also a language issue, like for a male person it would be "Sehr geehrter Herr McKenzie" - our adjective is gender specific, so we have to check the gender anyway.

I think for Germany we can completely agree with Rene's description. And especially with "Dr." being part of the name by law.

I think there needs to be an definitive/international agreement of whether Mr./Mrs/Herr/Frau... is part of the name prefix to avoid duplication when formulating letters etc.
IMO this is not a part of the name, since it depends on context and language and therefore should be generated at runtime as needed. It is going to be hard for systems doing it that way to determine whether they need to add the prefix to the name, as it contains an important part of the name (such as "Prof.", "Abu"...) or whether to drop the prefix to avoid duplication.
Especially when prefixes may end up containing a mixture of name parts and salutation like "Frau Prof.", "Mr. Abu"...
I wouldn't mind having a standard extension on HumanName to capture the preferred salutation, though.
it's certainly intended to be part of the title. I'm surprised this is an issue, actually

Well, this is not the first time we find names a hard thing to do :D

I'd like to repeat my question from above and clarify with an example
if I want to express the female Dr. Jane Smith (including "Mrs.") and need to differentiate between the salutation and the academic title, this would look like:

<name>
  <family value="Smith" />
  <given value="Jane" />
  <prefix value="Mrs.">
    <extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/iso21090-EN-qualifier">
      <valueCode value="???" />
    </extension>
  </prefix>
  <prefix value="Dr.">
    <extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/iso21090-EN-qualifier">
      <valueCode value="AC" />
    </extension>
  </prefix>
</name>

Would somebody please fill the question marks? ;-)
There isn't a code as yet. No one's had a need to be able to flag the gender/marital prefixes. That doesn't mean we couldn't add a new code if there's a need to be able to call it out.
Note that this is the same codes as in CDA. How is this done in CDA in germany?

As far as I know, prefix in German CDA IGs is only ever used for academic titles, one of the latest examples being http://download.hl7.de/documents/cdar2-arztbrief/ArztbriefPlus-v310.pdf
Still I believe it would technically be possible to add a gender-related prefix in there, since afaik there is no restriction to forbid that in the German templates. It's just that apparently nobody does that - administrativeGender seems to be the place to look at.
But maybe @dr Kai U. Heitmann can elaborate on that.
There is also the text property in Human name too, and I definitly would expect to find "Mr Brian Postlethwaite" or other formatting as locally used, or "Dr David Hay"
